item.title: One Bad Afternoon. Twenty-Three Years of Consequences.
item.description:
Birmingham International Airport, 1984.

A small elevated shuttle is running a 600-metre track at 42 km/h, carrying passengers between the terminal and the railway station. No wheels touching rails. No combustion. A linear induction motor — a horizontal electromagnetic field dragging a reaction plate through space — doing what wheels and pistons used to do.

The world’s first commercial maglev people mover. Running. Doing its job.

The man most responsible for the engineering principles underneath it wasn’t there. He was eight years into the institutional exile that had started with one bad afternoon in 1974.

item.title: Tesla Died with a Do-Not-Disturb Sign on His Door. Nineteen Days Later, They Took His Papers.
item.description:
The maid’s name was Alice Monaghan. She found the body January 8, 1943. The do-not-disturb sign had been on the door for two days. She eventually went in anyway, ignoring it.

Nikola Tesla was 86. He died of coronary thrombosis, alone in Room 3327 of the Hotel New Yorker. He’d been living there since 1933. The hotel gave him the room on credit. The man who invented the electrical grid that powered the hotel couldn’t pay his bill. Assistant Medical Examiner H.W. Wembly determined there were no suspicious circumstances.

item.title: He Received His Cosmogony in Thirty-Nine Days. The Silence Has Been Going for a Hundred Years.
item.description:
In May 1921, a painter and sculptor named Walter Russell went into a trance that lasted thirty-nine days.

Not a metaphor. His family consulted specialists to determine whether he needed to be committed. The specialists examined him and decided to let him continue. They were, according to accounts, impressed by what he was producing during the trance. They sensed, as one account puts it, “that something great was happening.”

What emerged from those thirty-nine days was a complete rewrite of atomic physics, organized around musical octaves, in which matter is not a thing but a condition.

item.title: They Solved the Marfa Lights. Nobody Bothered With What Was Left.
item.description: The official explanation for the Marfa Lights is correct. I want to be clear about that before anything else. Drive down U.S. 67 west of Alpine at night, and your headlights get refracted by the temperature inversion that forms every single evening in the high desert, warm air above and cold air pooling in the valley, exactly the optical conditions required for a Fata Morgana. The cold air bends your light upward. Observers at the state-funded viewing platform nine miles east of Marfa see floating orbs. It’s physics. It’s confirmed. A University of Texas at Dallas team drove down that highway in 2004, flashed their headlights, and watched them appear as mysterious lights from the platform. Atmospheric refraction. Mystery solved.
